Activity.title: Intuition behind the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus

Text.p: Derivatives measure how fast a function changes. Integrals measure how much a quantity accumulates. At first, the concepts may appear unrelated. The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (FTC) reveals the connection by showing that the derivative of an integral function equals the original integrand and that definite integrals can be computed through antiderivatives.

Imagine water flowing into a tank at a steady rate. An integral measures the accumulation of flow rate over time and gives the total amount of water in the tank. If the derivative of that accumulation function is taken, the result is the flow rate again. In other words, the derivative shows how fast the total is growing at each moment, matching the original inflow rate.
In this lesson, the inverse relationship between derivatives and integrals is explored, building intuition for the theorem.

ArcResource.title: Intuition behind the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus

MultipleChoice.question: How many liters of water are in the tank after 3\text{ minutes?}

choice.explanation: 2\text{ liters} corresponds to how much water is in the tank at t = 1\text{ minute,} not t = 3\text{ minutes.}
4\text{ liters} corresponds to how much water is in the tank at t = 2\text{ minutes,} not t = 3\text{ minutes.}
Examining the graph of F(x)\text{,} F(3) = 6\text{.} Or using the formula, F(3) = 2(3) = 6\text{.}

ShortAnswer.question: If F(x) = \int_0^x 2,dt\text{,} F'(5) = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}
ShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1, F'(x) = f(x)\text{.} Since f(t) = 2\text{, } F'(5) = f(5) = 2\text{.}

Hints.hint: By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1, F'(x) = f(x)\text{.}
Recall that f(t) = 2\text{,} so f(x) = 2\text{.}

Text.p: We will demonstrate that F'(x) = f(x)\text{.}

MultipleChoice.question: Graphically, F(x) represents the \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.label: secant line’s slope between t=0 and t=x
choice.explanation: The secant line’s slope represents the average rate of change of a function, but F(x) does not represent the average rate of change between t = 0 and t = x\text{.}

choice.label: tangent line’s slope to f(t) at t = x
choice.explanation: The tangent line’s slope represents the instantaneous rate of change of a function, but F(x) does not represent the instantaneous rate of change at t = x\text{.}

choice.label: area under f(t) between t = 0 and t = x
choice.explanation: By definition, F(x) = \displaystyle\int_0^x f(t)dt\text{,} which represents the area under f(t) from t=0 to t=x\text{.}

MultipleChoice.question: Contextually, F(x) can be interpreted as the car’s \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.label: acceleration at time t = x
choice.explanation: Acceleration is the derivative of velocity. But F(x) is defined as the integral of the velocity function f(t) from t = 0 to t = x\text{.}

choice.label: displacement between t = 0 and t = x
choice.explanation: By definition, F(x) = \displaystyle\int_0^x f(t)\,dt represents the accumulated change in position, or displacement, from the start time of t = 0 to a time t=x where 0 \leq x \leq 3\text{.}

choice.label: average velocity between t = 0 and t = 3
choice.explanation: Average velocity is found by dividing total displacement by elapsed time, not by computing the integral itself.

CorrectExplanation.p: The integral given by F(1) = \displaystyle\int_0^1 40 \; dt is the area under f(t) = 40 from t = 0 to t = 1\text{,} which is (40 \text{ miles per hour})(1 \text{ hour}) = 40 \text{ miles.} This area represents the car’s displacement or change in position from t = 0 to t = 1 \text{ hour,} which is 40 \text{ miles.}

Hints.hint: The integral given by F(1) = \displaystyle\int_0^1 40 \ dt represents the area under f(t) = 40 from t = 0 to t = 1\text{.}

CorrectExplanation.p: The integral given by F(2) = \displaystyle\int_0^2 40 \; dt is the area under f(t) = 40 from t = 0 to t = 2\text{,} which is (40 \text{ miles per hour})(2 \text{ hours}) = 80 \text{ miles.} This area represents the car’s displacement or change in position from t = 0 to t = 2 \text{ hours,} which is 80 \text{ miles.}

Hints.hint: The integral given by F(2) = \displaystyle\int_0^2 40 \ dt represents the area under f(t) = 40 from t = 0 to t = 2\text{.}

ShortAnswer.question: Based on the values we obtained for F(1) and F(2), F(x) = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.
ShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: The velocity is constant, so the displacement or change in position is a linear function. The points (1, F(1)) = (1, 40) and (2, F(2)) = (2, 80) are on the graph of F(x)\text{,} so we know that the slope is \frac{80-40}{2 - 1} = 40\text{,} which corresponds to the velocity. We also know that at t = 0\text{,} the displacement or change in position is F(0) = 0\text{,} so F(x) = 40x\text{.}

Hints.hint: The velocity is constant, so the displacement or change in position is a linear function.
The points (1, F(1)) = (1, 40) and (2, F(2)) = (2, 80) are on the graph of F(x)\text{.}

CorrectExplanation.p: Using the constant multiple and power rules, we obtain:
The key result is that if f satisfies certain conditions, then F'(x) = f(x)\text{.}

Hints.hint: Use the constant multiple and power rules.

Text.p: Lesson summary

list.item: The accumulation or integral function F(x) = \int_0^x f(t)\,dt measures total change.
The derivative of F(x) equals f(x), or F'(x) = f(x)\text{.}

Text.p: The previous lesson built intuition by showing how an accumulation function F(x) relates to a rate function f(x)\text{.} We now state this relationship as a theorem.

TheoremResource.title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1

Text.p: This result gives a direct way to differentiate integral functions. When an integral defines an accumulation function, the derivative of that function equals the original integrand.
In this lesson, we will apply the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (FTC) to examples that highlight different properties of integrals.

MultipleChoice.question: In the integral function F(x) = \int_1^x t^2 \,dt\text{,} we \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} replace t with any other variable.

choice.label: can
choice.explanation: The integral function F(x) = \int_1^x t^2 \, dt represents the area under the curve and depends entirely on x\text{,} not t\text{.} The variable of integration is t\text{,} but we can use any other variable, such as u\text{.} Ex: F(x) = \int_1^x t^2 \,dt = \int_1^x u^2 \,du

choice.label: cannot
choice.explanation: The integral function F(x) = \int_1^x t^2 \, dt represents the area under the curve and depends entirely on x\text{,} not t\text{.} The variable of integration is t\text{,} but we can use any other variable, such as u\text{.} Ex: F(x) = \int_1^x t^2 \,dt = \int_1^x u^2 \,du

MultipleChoice.question:
We want to find the derivative of the accumulation function F(x)\text{.}
So we \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} to find the derivative of the integrand f(t)\text{.}

choice.label: need
choice.explanation: We want to find the derivative of the accumulation function F(x) = \int_a^x f(t)\,dt\text{.} So the derivative of the integrand f(t) is not needed.

choice.label: do not need

MultipleChoice.question: Given F(x) = \displaystyle\int_2^x \ t^3 dt\text{,} F'(x) = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.explanation: The expression 3x^2 is the derivative of x^3, not of an integral function. The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus tells us that when the upper limit of integration is x\text{,} the derivative equals the integrand evaluated at x\text{,} not the derivative of the integrand.

The variable t is the variable of integration (also known as a placeholder or dummy variable) and does not appear in the final derivative. The derivative must be expressed in terms of x\text{,} the variable of the upper limit.
By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1, F'(x) = f(x) when F(x) = \int_a^x f(t)\ dt\text{.} Here f(t) = t^3\text{,} so F'(x) = x^3\text{.}

MultipleChoice.question: In applying FTC Part 1, the value of a \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} the derivative.

choice.label: affects
choice.explanation: The lower limit a serves only as the starting point of the accumulation. When differentiating F(x) = \int_a^x f(t)\ dt\text{,} the derivative depends only on x and the integrand f(t)\text{.} The constant a does not change the rate at which F(x) changes.

choice.label: does not affect
choice.explanation: By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1, F'(x) = f(x) for F(x) = \int_a^x f(t)\ dt\text{.} The lower limit a only shifts F(x) vertically, so a\text{’s} value has no effect on the derivative.

ShortAnswer.question: Given F(x) = \displaystyle\int_{3}^x \ (t^2 + 1) dt\text{,} F'(x) = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}
ShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: The derivative of F(x) is the integrand f(t) evaluated at t = x\text{.} Since f(t) = t^2 + 1\text{,} the derivative of F(x) is: F'(x) = f(x) = x^2 + 1

Hints.hint: The derivative of F(x) is the integrand f(t) = t^2 + 1 evaluated at t = x\text{.}

ShortAnswer.question: Given F(x) = \displaystyle\int_{-1}^x \sqrt{2t^3 - 5}\ dt\text{,} F'(x) = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}
ShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: The derivative of F(x) is the integrand f(t) evaluated at t = x\text{.} Since f(t) = \sqrt{2t^3 - 5}\text{,} the derivative of F(x) is: F'(x) = f(x) = \sqrt{2x^3 - 5}

Hints.hint: The derivative of F(x) is the integrand f(t) evaluated at t = x\text{.}

Text.p: Lesson summary

list.item: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1: If f is continuous on an interval and F(x) = \int_a^x f(t)\,dt\text{,} then F'(x) = f(x)\text{.}
The theorem applies when the lower limit of integration is a constant and the upper limit is the variable x\text{.}
The function F(x) represents the accumulated area under the curve of f from the fixed point a up to x\text{.}
Taking the derivative of F(x) recovers the original function f(x)\text{,} showing that differentiation and integration undo each other.
This connection unifies the two main branches of calculus: differentiation, which measures rate of change, and integration, which measures accumulation.
Graphically, the slope of F(x) at each point equals the height of f(x)\text{,} linking local behavior to total change.

Activity.title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1 with chain rule

Text.p: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus shows that differentiation and integration are connected because one process reverses the other. When the upper limit of an integral is x\text{,} the theorem says that F'(x)= f(x)\text{.} Sometimes the upper limit is a function like g(x) instead of x\text{.} In that case, the rate of change depends on both the integrand f and the way g(x) changes. The chain rule accounts for that upper limit, giving F'(x) = f(g(x)) \cdot g'(x)\text{.}
In this lesson, we will explore how to use the FTC together with the chain rule to find derivatives of integrals with upper a function as an upper limit.

ArcResource.title: Applying the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1 with chain rule

ShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: The integrand is f(t) = t^2 and g(x) = 3x + 5\text{.} So: f(g(x)) = f(3x+5) = (3x+5)^2

Hints.hint: Apply differentiation rules to find the derivative of g(x) = 3x + 5\text{.}

TextResource.Text: We want to find the derivative of F(x) = \displaystyle\int_5^{x^2 - 3x} 2t \ dt by determining that F(x) is a composition function and then applying the chain rule. So F'(x) = f(g(x)) \cdot g'(x).

MultipleChoice.question: The chain rule is needed because the \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.label: integrand is not x
choice.explanation: The variable of integration, t\text{,} does not affect whether the chain rule is needed. The chain rule applies when the limit of integration is a function of x\text{,} not because the integrand itself contains a different variable.

choice.label: upper limit is not x
choice.explanation: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1 gives F'(x) = f(g(x)) \cdot g'(x) when the upper limit is a function g(x)\text{.} The upper limit here is x^2 - 3x\text{,} so the chain rule is needed to multiply by the derivative of that expression.

choice.label: lower limit is not a constant
choice.explanation: The lower limit is 5\text{,} which remains constant. A changing lower limit would require an additional derivative term, but no such term appears in the integral.

ShortAnswer.question: The inner function is g(x) = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}
ShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: The expression that replaces x as the upper limit of integration in F(x) is g(x) = x^2 - 3x\text{,} which is the inner function for the composition.

Hints.hint: Identify the expression that replaces x as the upper limit of integration in F(x)\text{.}
Search for the function of x that appears inside the integral’s upper limit, above the constant 5\text{.}

ShortAnswer.question: The derivative of the inner function is g'(x) = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

Hints.hint: Differentiate g(x) = x^2 - 3x term by term.
Use the power rule for x^2 and the constant multiple rule for -3x\text{.} Combine both results to arrive at the final expression.

ShortAnswer.question: Previously, we found that the inner function is g(x) = x^2 - 3x with a derivative of g'(x) = 2x - 3\text{.} Using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1 and knowing that the integrand is f(t) = 2t\text{,} the derivative of the accumulation function is F'(x) = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

Hints.hint: Start by evaluating the integrand at the upper limit g(x)\text{.}
Substitute x^2 - 3x for t in f(t)\text{.} Then multiply the result by the derivative of g(x)\text{.}

Text.p: Given F(x) = \displaystyle\int_{-1}^{5x+7} \sqrt{t}\,dt\text{,} we will find F'(x) by viewing F(x) as a composition. We will first identify the inner function g(x)\text{,} and then apply the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1 together with the chain rule.

MultipleChoice.question: The inner function is g(x) = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.explanation: The variable x appears in the integral’s upper limit, but the entire expression above the constant -1 is 5x + 7\text{.} The chain rule applies to the full expression, not just x alone.
The inner function is the upper limit of integration when that limit depends on x. The upper limit equals 5x + 7\text{,} so g(x) = 5x + 7\text{.}
The function f(t) = \sqrt{t} is the integrand, not the inner function. The inner function comes from the bound of integration, while the integrand defines f(t) in the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.

ShortAnswer.question: We found earlier that the inner function is g(x) = 5x+7\text{.} So g'(x) = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

Hints.hint: Differentiate g(x) = 5x+7 term by term.
Use the power and constant multiple rule for 5x and the constant rule for 7\text{.} Combine both results to arrive at the final expression.
Start by evaluating the integrand at the upper limit g(x).
After substituting 5x+7 for t in f(t), multiply the result by the derivative of g(x).

Rule.title: Explain what happens when the limits of integration are reversed.
Rule.text: Reversing the limits of integration introduces a negative sign. So G'(x) = -F(x)\text{.}

Text.p: Given F(x) = \displaystyle\int_{x}^{x^3} t^2,dt\text{,} we will find F'(x)\text{.} We will write F(x) as a sum of integrals and then use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1 with the chain rule.

choice.explanation: Splitting the integral at zero fits the property \int_{a}^{c} f(t)\;dt = \int_{a}^{b} f(t)\;dt + \int_{b}^{c} f(t) \; dt with a = x\text{,} b = 0\text{,} and c = x^{3}\text{.} The first integral is evaluated from x down to 0\text{,} and the second integral is evaluated from 0 to x^3\text{.} This expression allows the use of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1 for each term.

The property \int_{a}^{c} f(t)\;dt = \int_{a}^{b} f(t)\;dt + \int_{b}^{c} f(t)\;dt requires the upper limit of the first integral to match the lower limit of the second integral. In this choice, both integrals start at zero, so the two parts do not connect properly to form a single continuous integral.

The sum \int_{x}^{x^{3}} t^{2}\;dt + \int_{0}^{x} t^{2}\;dt adds an extra integral from 0 to x that is not part of the original expression. The total represents more area than \displaystyle\int_{x}^{x^{3}} t^{2}\;dt unless x = 0\text{,} so the equality fails.

Hints.hint: Recall that the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1 says \dfrac{d}{dx}\left(\displaystyle\int_{a}^{x} f(t)\ dt\right) = f(x)\text{.} Compare that formula to the given integral and note whether x appears as an upper or lower limit.
When x is the lower limit of integration, a negative sign must be included before applying the Fundamental Theorem.
The inner function is g(x) = x^3\text{.}

question.p: First, we have rewritten F(x) = \displaystyle\int_{x}^{x^3} t^2 \; dt as a sum of integrals:

CorrectExplanation.p: We know that \dfrac{d}{dx} \left(\displaystyle\int_{x}^{0} t^2 \;dt \right)= -x^2 and \dfrac{d}{dx} \left(\displaystyle\int_{0}^{x^3} t^2 \;dt \right)= 3x^8\text{.} So:

hint.m: F(x) = \displaystyle\int_{x}^{x^3} t^2 \ dt = \displaystyle\int_{x}^{0} t^2 \ dt + \displaystyle\int_{0}^{x^3} t^2 \ dt

hint.p: We know that \dfrac{d}{dx} \left(\displaystyle\int_{x}^{0} t^2 \;dt \right) = -x^2 and \dfrac{d}{dx} \left(\displaystyle\int_{0}^{x^3} t^2 \;dt\right) = 3x^8\text{.}

Text.p: Lesson summary

list.item: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1 (with variable upper limit): If f is continuous and F(x) = \int_a^{g(x)} f(t)\,dt\text{,} then F'(x) = f(g(x)) \cdot g'(x)\text{.}
The theorem extends the earlier version, where the upper limit was x\text{,} to cases where the upper limit is another function g(x)\text{.}
The result combines the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus with the chain rule to account for how g(x) changes.
The derivative of an integral depends on both the integrand f(t) and the rate of change of the upper limit g(x)\text{.}
This connection reinforces that differentiation and integration remain inverse processes, even when the limits involve functions.

Text.p: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus has two parts. Recall that a definite integral is defined as the limit of Riemann sums, a process that builds a strong connection between area and accumulation. This definition is important; however, finding exact values is often more efficient through another approach. FTC Part 1 showed that the derivative of an integral function equals the original integrand. FTC Part 2 explains how to evaluate definite integrals directly by using an antiderivative.

TheoremResource.title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2
TheoremResource.Text:
If f(x) is continuous on [a,b] and F(x) is any antiderivative of f(x)\text{,} then:
\int_a^b f(x)\;dx = F(b) - F(a)

Text.p: This theorem says that a definite integral of f(x) can be computed by evaluating an antiderivative F(x) at the endpoints and subtracting: F(b) - F(a)\text{.} The notation F(x) \large|_{a}^{b} is sometimes used to represent this subtraction.
In this lesson, we will practice finding definite integrals by working with antiderivatives.

ShortAnswer.question: An antiderivative of f(x) = 2x is F(x) = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

CorrectExplanation.p: We want to find an antiderivative of f(x) = 2x\text{.} So we can use the power rule of integration:\int x^n \,dx = \frac{x^{n+1}}{n+1} + C\text{.}
Here, n = 1\text{,} so the family of antiderivatives is given by \int 2x \,dx = 2 \int x \,dx =2 \frac{x^2}{2} + C = x^2 + C where C is any constant like 0 or 1\text{.}
One particular antiderivative is F(x) = x^2\text{.}

Hints.hint: We need to find a function F(x) whose derivative is 2x\text{.}

We can apply the power rule for integration:
\int x^n \,dx = \frac{x^{n+1}}{n+1} + C

MultipleChoice.question: We \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} use any antiderivative when evaluating a definite integral.

choice.label: can
choice.explanation: Any antiderivative of the integrand can be used when evaluating a definite integral because the constant of integration cancels out during subtraction. Ex: \int_1^3 2x dx = (x^2 + 1)|_1^3 = ((3)^2 + 1) - ((1)^2 + 1) = 8

choice.label: cannot
choice.explanation: Any antiderivative of the integrand can be used when evaluating a definite integral because the constant of integration cancels out during subtraction.

Text.p: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2 states that a definite integral can be found by evaluating an antiderivative at the endpoints:

MultipleChoice.question: In the theorem, F(x) is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.label: the derivative of f(x)
choice.explanation: F(x) is not the derivative of f(x)\text{.} Rather, differentiating F(x) gives f(x)\text{.}

choice.label: the difference between f(x) and f(a)
choice.explanation: F(x) is not a difference between two values of f(x)\text{.} The difference appears only when evaluating F(b) - F(a) to find the value of the definite integral.

choice.label: an antiderivative of f(x)
choice.explanation: The function F(x) represents an antiderivative of f(x)\text{,} which means F'(x) = f(x)\text{.} The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2 connects the definite integral of f(x) with the values of its antiderivative at the endpoints.

MultipleChoice.question: In the theorem, F(b)-F(a) represents the \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.label: net area under f(x) from x = a to x = b
choice.explanation: F(b) - F(a) represents the net area under f(x) from x = a to x = b\text{.} Positive regions where f(x) > 0 add area, and negative regions where f(x) < 0 subtract area.

choice.label: total area between the curve and the x-axis
choice.explanation: The total area between the curve and the x-axis counts all regions as positive. The FTC gives the net area, which includes sign changes depending on whether f(x) is above or below the x-axis.

choice.label: tangent line’s slope to F(x) at x = b
choice.explanation: F(b) - F(a) is a difference in function values, not a slope. The tangent’s line slope to F(x) at x = b would be F'(b)\text{,} which equals f(b)\text{.}

TextResource.Text: We will evaluate the definite integral \displaystyle\int_0^4 (3x^2 + 1)\ dx\text{.} First, we will find an antiderivative F(x)\text{.} Then we will evaluate F(4) - F(0)\text{.}

MultipleChoice.question: An antiderivative for f(x)= 3x^2 + 1 is F(x) = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.explanation: 6x is the derivative of f(x) = 3x^2 + 1\text{,} not an antiderivative.

The power rule for integration was applied incorrectly for one of the terms. The power rule for integration is:
\int x^n \; dx = \frac{x^{n+1}}{n+1} + C
Applying this rule to find the antiderivative of 3x^2\text{,} we obtain:
\int 3x^2 \; dx = \frac{3x^{3}}{3} + C = x^3 + C

ShortAnswer.question:
Previously, we found an antiderivative F(x) = x^3 + x for our integrand 3x^2 + 1\text{.} We will use this antiderivative to evaluate the definite integral using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2:
\displaystyle\int_0^4 (3x^2 + 1) \; dx = F(4) - F(0)

LongAnswer.question: In evaluating the definite integral \displaystyle\int_0^4 (3x^2 + 1) \ dx\text{,} we used the antiderivative F(x) = x^3 + x\text{.} Could we have used another antiderivative? Explain.

Rule.title: Explain clearly whether or not a different antiderivative could also be valid.
Rule.text: Any antiderivative would be valid because the constants cancel out when subtracting the antiderivatives evaluated at x = 4 and at x = 0\text{.}

Rule.title: Provide an example or counterexample.
Rule.text: An example of another antiderivative would be G(x) = x^3 + x + 5\text{,} but any constant other than 5 would also work.

LongAnswer.ModelResponse:
Yes, another antiderivative could have been used to evaluate the definite integral, and the result would remain the same.
All antiderivatives of a function differ by a constant. Ex: If F(x) = x^3 + x is an antiderivative of f(x) = 3x^2 + 1\text{,} then any other antiderivative of f(x) must have the form F(x) + C, where C is a constant.
When evaluating the definite integral \displaystyle\int_0^4 (3x^2 + 1) \; dx\text{,} the result is found by computing F(4) - F(0)\text{.} Using a different antiderivative such as G(x) = x^3 + x + 5 would still give G(4) - G(0) = (x^3 + x + 5)\big|_0^4 = [F(4) + 5] - [F(0) + 5] = F(4) - F(0)\text{.} The constant 5 cancels during subtraction, so the final value of the definite integral is unchanged.

ShortAnswer.question: Evaluate the definite integral \displaystyle\int_{0}^9 \sqrt{x} \ dx\text{.}
ShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: Applying the power rule of integration and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2, we obtain: \begin{align*} \int_0^9 \sqrt{x} \; dx & = \int x^{1/2} \; dx\\ & = \left(\frac{x^{\frac{1}{2} + 1}}{\frac{1}{2} + 1}\right)\Big|_{0}^9 \\ & = \left(\frac{2}{3}x^{\frac{3}{2}} \right)\Big|_0^9\\ & = \frac{2}{3}(9)^{\frac{3}{2}} - \frac{2}{3}(0)^{\frac{3}{2}}\\ & = \frac{2}{3}(3)^3 \\ & = 18 \end{align*}

Hints.hint:
Use the antiderivative F(x) = \dfrac{2}{3} x^{\frac{3}{2}} to evaluate the definite integral by the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2:
\displaystyle\int_{0}^9 \sqrt{x} \; dx = F(9) - F(0)

Text.p: Lesson summary

list.item: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2: If f(x) is continuous on [a,b] and F(x) is any antiderivative of f(x)\text{,} then \int_a^b f(x)\,dx = F(b) - F(a)\text{.}
The theorem provides a direct way to evaluate a definite integral using an antiderivative rather than a Riemann sum.
The limits a and b mark the interval of accumulation. The difference F(b) - F(a) measures the total change in F across that interval.
Because F'(x) = f(x)\text{,} differentiation and integration act as inverse operations.
The notation F(x)\big|_a^b is a shorthand for evaluating F at the endpoints and subtracting.
This part of the theorem completes the link between accumulation (integration) and rate of change (differentiation) established in the FTC Part 1.

Activity.title: Integrals of even and odd functions

Text.p: Definite integrals measure the signed area under a curve. When a function’s graph has symmetry, that symmetry can greatly simplify the evaluation of definite integrals. A function can be even, odd, or neither, depending on how the function’s graph behaves.

A function f is even if f(-x)=f(x) for every x in the domain. The graph of an even function is symmetric about the y-axis. A function f is odd if f(-x)=-f(x) for every x in the domain. The graph of an odd function is symmetric about the origin.

image.description: Two graphs. Graph of an even function given by f(x) = x^2, which is decreasing from negative infinity to 0 and increasing from 0 to positive infinity. This graph is symmetric with respect to the y-axis. Graph of f(x) = x^3, which is increasing from negative infinity to positive infinity and changes concavity at x = 0. This graph is symmetric with respect to the origin.

Text.p: In this lesson, we will learn how to use these symmetries to simplify definite integrals of even and odd functions.

TheoremResource.title: Integrals of even and odd functions
TheoremResource.Text:
If a function f is continuous and even, that is, f(x) = f(-x) for all x in the domain of f, then:
\int_{-a}^a f(x) \; dx = 2 \int_0^a f(x) \; dx
If a function f is continuous and odd, that is, f(x) = -f(-x) for all x in the domain of f, then:
\int_{-a}^a f(x) \; dx = 0

ArcResource.title: Integrals of even and odd functions

MultipleChoice.question: If f is an even function, then the graph of f is symmetric about the \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.label: x-axis
choice.explanation: A function is symmetric about the x-axis if every point above the x-axis has a mirror image below the x-axis. But, for even functions, the graph above the x-axis is not mirrored below the x-axis.

choice.label: y-axis
choice.explanation: If f(-x) = f(x) for every x\text{,} then the graph is symmetric about the y-axis. Points to the right of the y-axis mirror those points to the left.

choice.label: origin
choice.explanation: Symmetry about the origin means mirroring across both axes. Even functions do not exhibit this mirroring. Ex: The first and third quadrants do not mirror for even functions.

MultipleChoice.question: The function f(x) = x^2 is even. So the definite integral of f over the interval [-3, 3] can be rewritten as: \displaystyle \int_{-3}^3 x^2 \, dx = \underline{\phantom{XXXXX}}

choice.explanation: The definite integral is over the interval [-3, 3]\text{.} So a = 3 and the upper limit of integration should be 3\text{,} not 2\text{.}
The definite integral \int_0^3 x^2 \, dx only gives half the area under the curve on [-3, 3]\text{.} We need to double it because f is even.
The interval should be [0, 3]\text{,} not [0, 2]\text{.} And the factor should be 2\text{,} not 3\text{.}
Using a = 3 and f(x) = x^2\text{,} we get \displaystyle \int_{-3}^3 x^2 \, dx = 2\int_0^3 x^2 \, dx because f is an even function.

MultipleChoice.question: The function \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} is an odd function.

choice.explanation: The graph of f(x) = x^2 is not symmetric about the origin, so f(x) = x^2 is not an odd function. Instead, the graph is symmetric about the y-axis and f(x) = x^2 is even.

The graph of f(x) = - \frac{1}{x} is symmetric about the origin, so f(x) = - \frac{1}{x} is an odd function.
Alternatively, substituting -x into f(x) gives:
f(-x) = - \frac{1}{-x} = \frac{1}{x} = - f(x)
Since f(-x) = -f(x)\text{,} f(x) is an odd function.
The graph of f(x) = \vert x \vert is not symmetric about the origin, so f(x) = \vert x \vert is not an odd function. Instead, the graph is symmetric about the y-axis and f(x) = \vert x \vert is even.

TextResource.Text: We will decide if each function is even, odd, or neither.

MultipleChoice.question: The function f(x) = x^4 is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.label: even
choice.explanation:
If we consider the graph of f(x) = x^4\text{,} we find that the graph is symmetric about the y-axis. So f(x) = x^4 is even.
Graph of f(x) = x^4
Alternatively, if we substitute -x into f(x) = x^4\text{,} we get:
f(-x) = (-x)^4 = x^4 = f(x)
We have shown that f(-x) = f(x) for every x\text{,} so f(x) = x^4 is an even function.

choice.label: odd
choice.explanation:
Graph of f(x) = x^4
The graph of f(x) = x^4 is not symmetric about the origin. So f is not odd.

choice.label: neither
choice.explanation:
Graph of f(x) = x^4
The graph of f(x) = x^4 does demonstrate one type of symmetry, so f is either even or odd.

MultipleChoice.question: The function f(x) = x^3 is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.label: even
choice.explanation:
Graph of f(x) = x^3
The graph of f(x) = x^3 is not symmetric about the y-axis. So f is not even.

choice.label: odd
choice.explanation:
If we consider the graph of f(x) = x^3\text{,} we find that the graph is symmetric about the origin. So f(x) = x^3 is odd.
Graph of f(x) = x^3
Alternatively, if we substitute -x into f(x) = x^3\text{,} we get:
f(-x) = (-x)^3 = -x^3 = -f(x)
We have shown that f(-x) = -f(x) for every x\text{,} so f(x) = x^3 is an odd function.

choice.label: neither
choice.explanation:
Graph of f(x) = x^3
The graph of f(x) = x^3 does demonstrate one type of symmetry, so f is either even or odd.

MultipleChoice.question: The function f(x) = \dfrac{1}{x} is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.label: even
choice.explanation:
Graph of f(x) = \frac{1}{x}
The graph of f(x) = \frac{1}{x} is not symmetric about the y-axis. So f is not even.

choice.label: odd
choice.explanation:
If we consider the graph of f(x) = \frac{1}{x}\text{,} we find that the graph is symmetric about the origin. So f(x) = \frac{1}{x} is odd.
Graph of f(x) = \frac{1}{x}
Alternatively, if we substitute -x into f(x) = \frac{1}{x}\text{,} we get:
f(-x) = \frac{1}{-x} = -\frac{1}{x} = -f(x)
We have shown that f(-x) = -f(x) for every x\text{,} so f(x) = \frac{1}{x} is an odd function.

choice.label: neither

MultipleChoice.question: The function f(x) = (x+1)^2 is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.label: even
choice.explanation:
Graph of f(x) = (x+1)^2
The graph of f(x) = (x+1)^2 is not symmetric about the y-axis. So f is not even.
We have found that x^2 is even while (x+1)^2 is not even. A function with an even power is not always an even function. We still need to check for symmetry.

choice.label: odd
choice.explanation:
Graph of f(x) = (x+1)^2
The graph of f(x) = (x+1)^2 is not symmetric about the origin. So f is not odd.

choice.label: neither
choice.explanation:
If we consider the graph of f(x) = (x+1)^2\text{,} we find that the graph is not symmetric about the y-axis or about the origin. So f(x) = (x+1)^2 is neither even nor odd.
Graph of f(x) = (x+1)^2
Alternatively, if we substitute -x into f(x) = (x+1)^2\text{,} we get:
f(-x) = (-x+1)^2
The function value f(-x) = (-x +1)^2 is not equal to f(x) = (x+1)^2\text{,} so f is not even. The function value f(-x) = (-x +1)^2 is not equal to -f(x) = -(x+1)^2\text{,} so f is not odd. Again, f is neither even nor odd.

MultipleChoice.question: The function f(x) = x^3 + 1 is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.label: even
choice.explanation:
Graph of f(x) = x^3 + 1
The graph of f(x) = x^3 + 1 is not symmetric about the y-axis. So f is not even.

choice.label: odd
choice.explanation:
Graph of f(x) = x^3 + 1
The graph of f(x) = x^3 + 1 is not symmetric about the origin. So f is not odd.
We have found that x^3 is odd, while x^3 + 1 is not odd. A function with an odd power is not always an odd function. We still need to check for symmetry.

choice.label: neither
choice.explanation:
If we consider the graph of f(x) = x^3 + 1\text{,} we find that the graph is not symmetric about the y-axis or about the origin. So f(x) = x^3 + 1 is neither even nor odd.
Graph of f(x) = x^3 + 1
Alternatively, if we substitute -x into f(x) = x^3 + 1\text{,} we get:
f(-x) = (-x)^3 + 1 = -x^3 + 1
The function value f(-x) = -x^3 + 1 is not equal to f(x) = x^3 + 1\text{,} so f is not even. The function value f(-x) = -x^3 + 1 is not equal to -f(x) = -(x^3 + 1) = -x^3 - 1\text{,} so f is not odd. Again, f is neither even nor odd.

MultipleChoice.question: The function f(x) = x^4 + 1 is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.label: even
choice.explanation:
If we consider the graph of f(x) = x^4+1\text{,} we find that the graph is symmetric about the y-axis. So f(x) = x^4+1 is even.
Graph of f(x) = x^4+1
Alternatively, if we substitute -x into f(x) = x^4+1\text{,} we get:
f(-x) = (-x)^4+1 = x^4+1 = f(x)
We have shown that f(-x) = f(x) for every x\text{,} so f(x) = x^4+1 is an even function.

choice.label: odd
choice.explanation:
Graph of f(x) = x^4+1
The graph of f(x) = x^4+1 is not symmetric about the origin. So f is not odd.

choice.label: neither
choice.explanation:
Graph of f(x) = x^4+1
The graph of f(x) = x^4+1 does demonstrate one type of symmetry, so f is either even or odd.

MultipleChoice.question: The definite integral \displaystyle \int_{-5}^5 x^2 \ dx \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.label: can be rewritten as 2 \displaystyle \int_0^5 x^2 \ dx
choice.explanation:
If we consider the graph of f(x) = x^2\text{,} we find that the graph is symmetric about the y-axis. So f(x) = x^2 is even.
Graph of f(x) = x^2
The definite integral of the even function f(x) = x^2 over the symmetric interval [-5, 5] can then be rewritten as:
\displaystyle \int_{-5}^5 x^2 \, dx = 2 \displaystyle \int_0^5 x^2 \, dx

choice.label: is equal to 0
choice.explanation:
Graph of f(x) = x^2
The graph of f(x) = x^2 is not symmetric about the origin. So f is not odd and we cannot use the symmetry to assume that the definite integral is equal to 0\text{.}

choice.label: cannot be rewritten
choice.explanation:
Graph of f(x) = x^2
The graph of f(x) = x^2 does demonstrate one type of symmetry, so f is either even or odd. So the definite integral \displaystyle \int_{-5}^5 x^2 \ dx can be rewritten using the symmetry.

Hints.hint: Use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2 to find \displaystyle \int_0^5 x^2 \ dx\text{.}
Multiply the result of integration over [0, 5] by 2 to find the integral over [-5, 5]\text{.}

TextResource.Text: We will calculate \displaystyle \int_{a}^b 2x \ dx over different intervals [a, b]\text{.}

MultipleChoice.question: The definite integral \displaystyle \int_{-5}^5 2x \ dx \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

explanation.p: The graph of f(x) = 2x is not symmetric about the y-axis. So f is not even, and we cannot rewrite the integral as \displaystyle \int_0^5 2x \, dx\text{.}

choice.label: is equal to 0
choice.explanation:
If we consider the graph of f(x) = 2x\text{,} we find that the graph is symmetric about the origin. So f(x) = 2x is odd.
Signed area between the graph of f(x) = 2x and the x-axis over [-5, 5]
The definite integral of the odd function f(x) = 2x over the symmetric interval [-5, 5] can then be rewritten as
\displaystyle \int_{-5}^5 x^2 \, dx = 0
because the positive area under the graph from x = 0 to x =5 will cancel with the negative area from x = -5 to x =0\text{.}

choice.label: cannot be rewritten
choice.explanation:
Graph of f(x) = 2x
The graph of f(x) = 2x does demonstrate one type of symmetry, so f is either even or odd. So the definite integral \displaystyle \int_{-5}^5 2x \ dx can be rewritten using the symmetry.

question.p: In the previous part, we considered the integral of the odd function f(x) = 2x over the interval [-5, 5]\text{.} We now consider the same integral over the interval [-1, 3]\text{.}

Hints.hint: The interval [-1, 3] is not a symmetric interval of the form [-a, a]\text{.}
Use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2 to find \displaystyle \int_{-1}^3 2x \ dx\text{.}

Text.p: Lesson summary

list.item: Symmetries can be used to simplify calculations of some definite integrals.
A function f is even if f(-x) = f(x) for every x in the domain.
If f is continuous and even, then \displaystyle \int_{-a}^a f(x) \, dx = 2 \displaystyle \int_0^a f(x) \, dx\text{.}
A function f is odd if f(-x) = -f(x) for every x in the domain.
If f is continuous and odd, then \displaystyle \int_{-a}^a f(x) \, dx = 0\text{.}

CorrectExplanation.p: With x as the upper limit and a constant #a# as the lower limit, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1 tells us that the derivative of the integral equals the integrand evaluated at the upper limit. The integrand is f(t) = #b#t^{#c#} + #d#\text{.}

hint.p: The derivative of F(x) is equal to the integrand evaluated at t = x\text{.}

RandomizedShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: We notice that x is the lower limit and #a# is the constant upper limit. We want to apply the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1, so we use the property: \int_a^x f(t) \; dt = -\int_x^a f(t) \; dt Using this property, we can rewrite: F(x) = \displaystyle\int_x^{#a#} (#b#t^2 - #c#t + #d#) \; dt = - \displaystyle \int_{#a#}^{x} (#b#t^2 - #c#t + #d#) \; dt By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1, the derivative of this integral is the negative of the integrand evaluated at the upper limit. The integrand is f(t) = #b#t^2 - #c#t + #d#\text{.} So: F' (x) = - f(x) = -#b#x^2 + #c#x - #d#

hint.p: Use the property \int_a^x f(t) \; dt = -\int_x^a f(t) \; dt\text{.}

CorrectExplanation.p: According to the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1 and applying the chain rule, if F(x) = \displaystyle\int_{a}^{g(x)} f(t) \; dt\text{,}

The integrand is f(t) = \dfrac{1}{t + #d#} and g' (x) = #b#x^{#n#}\text{.} So:\begin{align} F'(x) & = \dfrac{1}{x^{#b#} + #c# +#d#} \cdot (#b#x^{#n#}) \\ & = \dfrac{#b#x^{#n#}}{x^{#b#} + #m#}\end{align}

hint.p: Given F(x) = \displaystyle\int_{a}^{g(x)} f(t) \; dt\text{, } F^\prime (x) = f(g(x)) \cdot g^\prime(x)\text{.}

RandomizedShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation:
We can rewrite F(x) as a sum of two integrals using the sum property of integrals, which states:
\int_p^r f(t) \, dt = \int_p^q f(t) \, dt + \int_q^r f(t) \, dt
Using this property, we introduce a constant q = #e# and write:
\begin{align} F(x) &= \int_{x^{#a#}}^{#e#} (#c#t^3 + #d#) \, dt + \int_{#e#} ^{#b#^x} (#c#t^3 + #d#) \, dt \\ &= -\int_{#e#} ^{x^{#a#}} (#c#t^3 + #d#) \, dt + \int_{#e#} ^{#b#^x} (#c#t^3 + #d#) \, dt. \end{align}
According to the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1, and applying the chain rule when both limits depend on x\text{,} we differentiate each term:
F'(x) = \frac{d}{dx} \left[ -\int_{#e#} ^{x^{#a#}} (#c#t^3 + #d#) \, dt \right] + \frac{d}{dx} \left[ \int_{#e#} ^{#b#^x} (#c#t^3 + #d#) \, dt \right]
So:
\begin{align} F'(x) &= -f(x^{#a#}) \cdot (#a#x^{#n#}) + f(#b#^x) \cdot (#b#^x \ln #b#) \\ &= -(#c#(x^{#a#})^3 + #d#)(#a#x^{#n#}) + (#c#(#b#^x)^3 + #d#)(#b#^x \ln #b#) \\ &= -(#c#x^{#multi#} + #d#)(#a#x^{#n#}) + (#c# \cdot #b#^{3x} + #d#)(#b#^x \ln #b#). \end{align}

hint.p: We can split F(x) as a sum of integrals, so we can use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1 with the chain rule:

TextResource.Text:
We will use odd or even properties of a function to simplify evaluation of the definite integral:
\int_{-1}^{1} 3x^2 + 1 \; dx

MultipleChoice.question: The function f(x) = 3x^2 + 1 is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}\text{.}

choice.label: odd
even
choice.explanation: The function f(x) = 3x^2 + 1 is even because f(-x) = 3(-x)^2 + 1 = 3x^2 + 1 = f(x)\text{.} A function f is even if f(-x) = f(x) for all x\text{.}

explanation.p: The function satisfies f(-x) = f(x) for all x\text{,} so f is even, not neither even nor odd.

question.p: Using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2, evaluate the definite integral \int_{0}^1 (3x^2 + 1)\text{.}

CorrectExplanation.p: An antiderivative of f(x) = 3x^2 + 1 is F(x) = x^3 + x\text{.} Using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2:
So the value of the definite integral is 2\text{.}

hint.p: Find an antiderivative F(x) of f(x) = 3x^2 + 1\text{.} Then apply the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2 using:\int_{0}^{1} f(x)\,dx = F(1) - F(0)

ShortAnswer.question: Using properties of even functions, evaluate \int_{-1}^{1} 3x^2 + 1 \; dx \text{.}

Hints.hint: If f is an even function, then \int_{-1}^1 f(x) \; dx = 2 \int_0^1 f(x) \; dx\text{.}

RandomizedShortAnswer.question:
Without using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2, evaluate the definite integral:
\displaystyle \int_{-#a#}^{#a#} #b#x^3 \\, dx
RandomizedShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: Given f(x) = #b#x^3\text{,} we know that f(-x) = #b#(-x)^3 = -#b#x^3 = -f(x)\text{,} so f is odd. Since f is odd, the definite integral \displaystyle\int_{-#a#}^{#a#} #b#x^3 \\, dx evaluates to 0\text{.}

Hints.hint: If f is odd, then \displaystyle \int_{-#a#}^{#a#} f(x) \\, dx = 0\text{.}
